Expectation1: Communicate with pilots to provide instructions and updates
Situation1: A pilot declares low fuel on approach and needs immediate vectors to the nearest runway.
Expectation2: Engage in spiritual study and reflection
Situation2: Their teacher invited them to summarize key teachings for a temple session tomorrow.
Story: The headset pressed against my ears, the radar screen glowing in the dim light. “Tower, this is Flight 237, low fuel, requesting immediate vectors.” My heart thudded. Every second mattered. I toggled the mic, voice steady, mind racing through procedures. The pilots depended on me for calm, precise guidance. Yet, in the back of my mind, the words of my teacher echoed: “Tomorrow, you will share the essence of the Dharma with the sangha.” I had promised to prepare a summary, to reflect deeply, to honor the teachings. But the day had slipped away in a blur of flight paths and radio chatter. Now, as I juggled the urgent needs of the cockpit and the silent call of the temple, I felt the tension coil inside me. The world demanded my focus, my clarity, my compassion—both in the control tower and on the meditation cushion. I stared at the blinking blip on the screen, the pilot’s voice crackling with anxiety, and felt the weight of two worlds pressing in, each asking for all of me.
